{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3333701,"name":"Naroglu","username":"vuure","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/v/8dc957/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-03-15T13:00:55.949Z","cooked":"

We are using ADXRS450 gyro and trying to program Field-Oriented mecanum drive. Problem is, it is not working. The front changes everytime, as i can explain (I cant explain because i don’t know what is wrong). I tried to print the rotation2d variable and it looks like it is working (i think problem is not about gyro). Here is the code:

Defining Mecanumdrive and gyro:

ADXRS450_Gyro gyro = new ADXRS450_Gyro();

WPI_VictorSPX backright = new WPI_VictorSPX(23);
  WPI_VictorSPX frontright = new WPI_VictorSPX(22);
  WPI_TalonSRX frontleft = new WPI_TalonSRX(24);
  WPI_VictorSPX backleft = new WPI_VictorSPX(25);

  MecanumDrive m_robotDrive = new MecanumDrive(frontleft, backleft, frontright, backright);

Using them on TeleOp:

Rotation2d rotation2d = gyro.getRotation2d();

m_robotDrive.driveCartesian(-controller.getRawAxis(1), controller.getRawAxis(0), controller.getRawAxis(4), rotation2d);

Could you post your full code?

What do you mean by the front changes every time? Every time you turn the robot on? Or start driving? Does the “front” seem to drift as you rotate?

Can you verify your gryo increases when the robot rotates ccw?

Naroglu:

The front changes everytime

When you say this, are you meaning that the front changes while it’s enabled, when you enable/disable the robot, or when you turn the robot on or off?

If you haven’t already, try running “gyro.reset()” in robotInit() or teleopInit(), which should set the front to whatever direction the robot is facing when the robot turns on or enters teleop respectively.

more info here

i will send robot code soon when i arrive at the team’s workshop.

I meant front and any others directions changes when i turned the robot. For example if its looking to the front wall of the room and when i give “go forward” command, it goes to the front wall. But if it is looking to the left wall and when i give “go forward” command, it goes to the right wall.

I verified gyro works perfectly by defining it same as code and 'sysout’ing it.

m_robotDrive.driveCartesian(-controller.getRawAxis(1), controller.getRawAxis(0)

Your lateral joystick may need to be inverted here

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":21,"updated_at":"2024-03-16T07:05:37.582Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":77,"readers_count":76,"score":20.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":458756,"topic_slug":"problem-with-field-oriented-mecanum-drive","display_username":"Naroglu","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://github.com/vuure/6430testcode/blob/main/Robot.java","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"6430testcode/Robot.java at main · vuure/6430testcode · GitHub","clicks":6}],"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":55131,"username":"bmcdonnell41","name":"Brandon","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/b/35a633/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":60285,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/problem-with-field-oriented-mecanum-drive/458756/11","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3334401,"name":"Brandon","username":"bmcdonnell41","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/b/35a633/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-03-16T13:06:03.969Z","cooked":"

Ok, let’s try debugging a few things. First can you read over this section:

FIRST Robotics Competition Documentation

Using the WPILib Classes to Drive your Robot

WPILib includes many classes to help make your robot get driving faster. Standard drivetrains: Differential Drive Robots: The wiring of a simple differential drive robot. These drive bases typicall...

Let’s make sure when you pass a positive value in to your drive function for y, you go left. When you pass in a positive x, you go forward. You can also pass a positive rotation you rotate ccw. When you pass negative values, they should be reversed. Let’s also look at the gyro values while testing this, when the rotation going into the drive function is positive, the gyro should be getting more positive.

You are negating the joystick values, and that is typically correct. So we need to pass in a negative value to give a positive value to the drive train. In the driver station, you can look at the joystick values, I think under the usb symbol. If you hover your mouse over it you can see the raw values.

The code was wrong when i uploaded and i updted it. When Y gets negative value, robot goes forward. When X gets negative value, robot goes right. When robot turns counter clockwise, gyro value increases.

Are we looking at the y values from the joystick perspective or drive train?

If it is drivetrain, this is likely part of the problem.

Can you add some code above your driveCartesian call:

double xSpeed = -controller.getRawAxis(1);
Smart dashboard.putNumber(“xSpeed”, xSpeed);

And please do the same for ySpeed and zRotation.

Then call :
driveCartesian(xSpeed, ySpeed, zRotation, gryo)

Then when you test directions, check if zRotation is positive when robot goes ccw.

What kind of joystick is being used?

getRotation2D() returns a rotation2D object, not an angle

I don’t think there’s an easy way to flip the angle, but one somewhat janky solution might be to replace this line:

Rotation2d rotation2d = gyro.getRotation2d();

with these lines:

Rotation2d gyroRotation2d = gyro.getRotation2d();
Rotation2d rotation2d = Rotation2d.fromDegrees(-gyroRotation2d.getDegrees()));

The idea is that you get the angle value from the Rotation2d object you get from the gyro, then make a new Rotation2d object with the flipped angle.
